244663: Sun Quan, Lord of Wu.author: Aquillion
244663: Sun Quan, Lord of Wu.text_parsed:
@Evil_Tactics: It's a pity they didn't include any legends from Legends. Granted that most of them sucked, and even the cool ones were often pretty generic by modern standards (Adun Oakenshield, say; Angus Mackenzie is very usable but probably bad for the game.)

Rasputin Dreamweaver would have been nice, though -- he's an interesting card that almost no modern players have ever gotten to play. Hazezon Tamar is cool, too, if a bit overpriced.

Unfortunately they're probably all on the reserved list, now that I think about it. Why doesn't WotC just remove everything but the Power Nine from that list? Do they really think anyone still cares?

244663: Sun Quan, Lord of Wu.author: DarthParallax
244663: Sun Quan, Lord of Wu.text_parsed:
While it is true that there were too many Alara Block Legends in the set, I have noticed, with the Power Creep of creatures and whatnot, that basically...well, a lot of the good Commanders DO come from Alara, for certain color identities. :/

3-Colors seems to be Optimal Colors for Commander. Not 2, you don't get enough variety of spells- either your games get 'stale' (very similar to each other, whether your deck is power-balanced or not), or your deck actually has vulnerabilities. Since Alara was the first block to have 3-colored Legends since....Legends..umm...Rafiq of the Many, now in 2013, I believe still deserves to be in the Vault. Kresh does not. Sharuum I am not sure of.

1., 2. An Elder Dragon, plus one other Legends Legend (not all of them are Reserved)
3. (1) ONE Portal Legend (this guy),
4.,5. 2 Weatherlight Legends (Captain Sisay and Gerard Capashen- because you HAVE to have Gerrard, I think),
6.,7. 2 Time Spiral Legends (Teferi and Jhoira of the Ghitu),
8. one Mirari-Arc Legend (Akroma, Phage, Kamahl

That covers "Old Skool"
But leaves room for "New Hotness"
Face it- Modern Legends are better now.

9. A Guild Legend (Momir Vig or Rakdos, the Defiler?)
10. A Shard Legend (Rafiq)
11. A Hybrid Legend (Oona)
12. An Eldrazi (Ulamog)
13. Innistrad Preview (Mikaeus)
14. A Phyrexian Legend (Skithyrix or Glissa, the Traitor or a Praetor)
15. A Kamigawa Legend (Kiki-Jiki)

This means we lose Doran. Or we cut Kiki-Jiki. And maybe two Legends Legends is too many, but still lose a Pit Fighter. And Progenitus.
From the Vault: Legends really would have benefitted from being 20 cards large...because both the old and new kinda needed to be in.

244664: Sharuum the Hegemon.author: Lyriq
244664: Sharuum the Hegemon.text_parsed:
The first commander deck I ever built myself (with a little help from Archenemy). Very easy to get her effect multiple times per turn. Crystal Shard, Erratic Portal, Master Transmuter, Venser the Sojourner, Esperzoa, Conjurer's Closet, I could go on.

My favorite play with her was in a three (remaining) player game. I had soulscoured, but one opponent was playing Omnath, Locus of Mana, and had out a caged sun. I had about 12 mana in artifacts, but in response to the casting, both opponents blew a few up, though not including my unwinding clock, so no player was in any position to make a big play. Eventually, Omnath draws a forest or two and quickly gets out a Primeval Titan, and starts ramping back up again. Luckily enough for me, I finally draw a fifth mana, allowing me to drop a Tezzeret the Seeker grabbing Master Transmuter which let me put out Platinum Angel (as I was sitting at 4 life), then Sharuum who had been sitting in my hand since I returned her there earlier in the game. I grabbed Magister Sphinx and swung for lethal.

Those guys don't want to play with me anymore.
244664: Sharuum the Hegemon.text_posted:
The first commander deck I ever built myself (with a little help from Archenemy). Very easy to get her effect multiple times per turn. [autocard]Crystal Shard[/autocard], [autocard]Erratic Portal[/autocard], [autocard]Master Transmuter[/autocard], [autocard]Venser the Sojourner[/autocard], [autocard]Esperzoa[/autocard], [autocard]Conjurer's Closet[/autocard], I could go on.

My favorite play with her was in a three (remaining) player game. I had [autocard]soulscour[/autocard]ed, but one opponent was playing [autocard]Omnath, Locus of Mana[/autocard], and had out a caged sun. I had about 12 mana in artifacts, but in response to the casting, both opponents blew a few up, though not including my [autocard]unwinding clock[/autocard],  so no player was in any position to make a big play. Eventually, Omnath draws a forest or two and quickly gets out a [autocard]Primeval Titan[/autocard], and starts ramping back up again. Luckily enough for me, I finally draw a fifth mana, allowing me to drop a [autocard]Tezzeret the Seeker[/autocard] grabbing [autocard]Master Transmuter[/autocard] which let me put out [autocard]Platinum Angel[/autocard] (as I was sitting at 4 life), then Sharuum who had been sitting in my hand since I returned her there earlier in the game. I grabbed [autocard]Magister Sphinx[/autocard] and swung for lethal.

Those guys don't want to play with me anymore.

244664: Sharuum the Hegemon.author: Ferlord
244664: Sharuum the Hegemon.text_parsed:
Ok, so here's the deal:

I was playing a friend who was experimenting with a Sharuum EDh deck. It was pretty good, since he only played Standard around Scars of Mirrodin, meaning he had a lot of artifacts (he also had this asinine Master Transmuter deck with Blight-... never mind).

So at some point in time, he had the following: Sharuum, Contagion Engine, Mindslaver, and Everflowing Chalice.

So, he was going to attack me, then Mindslaver me. On that turn, he noticed that I had a Damnation in my hand, so unless he had a way to kill Sharuum and get an extra mana to bring her back each turn, I'd at least survive a few more turns.

It all turned grim when I realized that I played No Mercy a few turns ago.

So here's what happened: Sharuum attacks, dealing damage, then getting killed by No Mercy. He'd then Proliferate with Contagion Engine, giving Everflowing Chalice an additional 2 counters (or + mana gained from it). He'd sacrifice Mindslaver, and then replay Sharuum with the extra mana he got accounting for the extra commander cost, so he could return Mindslaver to the field..

He got pseudo-infinite turns, winning the game.

So if you want an infinite combo with Sharuum, you'll need Contagion Engine, Mindslaver, and Everflowing Chalice. You'll also need your opponent to play No Mercy (or Donate it if you want).

Added together, that's needed per turn (not considering the extra per death, because it's taken care of)

244665: Captain Sisay.author: JaxsonBateman
244665: Captain Sisay.text_parsed:
Most people include her in GWx commander decks because, well, she's a reusable tutor that can get lots of powerful stuff, so why wouldn't you.

But, the thing is, she's an awesome commander herself. Having her as the actual commander guarantees you'll always be able to access her. She's in the ramp color of green, so turn 3 is reliable, and thanks to cards like Sol Ring, Mana Vault and Mana Crypt she can even come out on turn 2. As for her ability herself in a commander deck built around it... wow. She can search for silver bullets. She can search for bombs. She can search for game enders. She basically gets what you need to get into the dominant position.

My default gameplan when I'm using her deck is to first get out ramp to be able to reach 9 mana (can often get it simply with either Rofellos or Gaea's Cradle, but sometimes you'll need both), and then plop down an Iona. It's pretty hard for most decks to have cards of multiple colors that can deal with her. And even if they do, if you've got the mana to hardcast Iona, that means the turn after you should be able to hardcast Avacyn.

A one-card combo engine that you're guaranteed to have because she's your commander. Can't complain.

244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.author: Andrays
244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.text_parsed:
This guy is awesome in so many ways...

For starters, he completely changes how combat works. He lets you attack in situations where trading would normally put you at a disadvantage. Copy a lord-type card and pump your dudes for a turn, or crash in aggressively with a throw-away token. On the defensive side of things, attackers have to play around the prospect of consistently trading with or being chump-blocked by expendable copies.

Also, he combos with practically everything, most obviously Intruder Alarm. Any fatty or creature with useful enter/leave-the-battlefield ability is also a prime candidate for mirroring. Copy my evoked Mulldrifter, and attack with the copy? Yes please!

While Mirror Gallery and this card made all sorts of lights go off in my brain, his ability doesn't work on legendary creatures, so exponential gratuitous goblin goodness is out of the question. Still, the only thing I can think of that's better than having one Kiki out is two (or four)!

244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.author: JungaThunda
244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.text_parsed:
Make sure your opponent has all his creatures tapped (or Lightning Bolt the only blocker) and most of his lands as well...
Attach Breath of Fury to Goblin Lackey to attack to put down Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker (this card) to tap to copy Goblin Lackey, and attach Breath of Fury to it, (and this is all on the stack before sacrificing the actual Goblin Lackey because of Breath of Fury). Then you get an additional combat stage and untap all creatures, copy the Goblin Lackey token, then attack with the one with Breath of Fury, attach it to the other Goblin Lackey token and rinse and repeat! And yeah you can put a stronger Goblin because of Goblin Lackey, feel free to copy and replace Breath of Fury with that stronger Goblin, to just make the game end quicker. Then you keep on attacking forever till your opponent is dead. Game over. No need to attack anymore. No fun to just keep attacking the dead. xD

244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.author: Ragamander
244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.text_parsed:
Kiki's card design is really cool, and I love cards like this (ones with interesting effects and lots of different interactions with other cards), but I feel like something went a little wrong somewhere for him to be so easy to break.

So yeah, I know it's practically irrelevant because Kiki-Jiki goes infinite with about a gazillion different creatures, but I still want to note that his tokens can be made permanent with Sundial of the Infinite by exiling the one-time triggered ability to sacrifice them.

Also, if you use Selesnya's new "Populate" mechanic, you can make permanent duplicates any of Kiki's copies. These duplicate copies will have haste, but they won't have to be sacrificed, since that clause is part of Kiki-Jiki's text and not the token's, so it is not copied. This applies to any Clone effect, but Populate is probably a little easier to spam.

It might be fun to try to abuse these in a casual context where players might frown upon the infinite combos. I'm usually all about infinite combos, but I really do feel like Kiki-Jiki makes it a little too easy.

I mean, he's tutorable even with Time of Need and Goblin Matron for God's sake, and there are so many cards that combo off infinitely with him that drawing one won't be much of a problem. And four of those have Flash (Pestermite, Deceiver Exarch, Village Bell-Ringer, and Restoration Angel), meaning you can sneak them into play when your opponent isn't expecting them, then untap into Kiki-Jiki in all his hasty glory. And you can protect the whole thing with Dovescape! Mana Short, Silence, Thorn of Amethyst, and other such cards are also pretty simple ways to all but guarantee a smooth execution.

However, I will make one contribution to the list of combo enablers:

You can make Necrotic Ooze copy itself infinitely if Kiki-Jiki is in the graveyard. Pandemonium ensues. Actually, since the copies will all hit the graveyard at the end of your turn, you could win with Blood Artist or any number of things that fit the curve better. For example, a Grimgrin in the 'yard lets you attack with an infinite number of infinitely large Oozes.
T1: Swamp, Dark Ritual, Buried Alive (Grimgrin, Kiki-Jiki, Necrotic Ooze, in that order)
T2: Land, Shallow Grave, go infinite

Pretty tantalizing, eh?

244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.author: TyomDrettar
244666: Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker.text_parsed:
I love the new art for this card and it seems like an incredibly appropriate choice for From the Vault: Legends. This card acts as a win condition with Deceiver Exarch and Restoration Angel - by creating infinite haste tokens the turn it enters the battlefield (because when the tokens enter they either untap or blink Kiki-Jiki allowing the process to be repeated) and similarly with Thornbite Staff and Tar Pitcher.

Attach a Thornbite Staff to Kiki-Jiki and also a Thornbite Staff to Tar Pitcher (made easier by the free equip cost to Shamans) and copy the Tar Pitcher. Then use the original Tar Pitcher to sacrifice the token dealing 2 damage to an opponent. This untaps Kiki-Jiki and the Tar Pitcher for this process to be repeated infinitely. Although there are lots of similar combos such as with Skirk Prospector and Fireball like burn spells, these Thornbite Staff combos are much more difficult to execute due to volume of cards required to make this combo work. However, it does allow a deck to keep to a mono-red theme.

Also, Sundial of the Infinite can make any tokens Kiki-Jiki produces permanent.

And finally, if you can't be bothered to make a deck around him, he's a power house in any ramp creature decks (or any creature deck for that matter). Free haste Eldrazis sound nice to anyone?

Combos like this are a sign of the power Kiki-Jiki has and its nice to see some bolder and older reprints for From the Vault series.

5/5

244667: Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.author: Faralay
244667: Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.text_parsed:
@Ferlord, that "odd" body ensures that opponents using Blue's nemesis color will have to zap it at least twice. (Well, four times if we're being literal). They have to spend their own turn taking care of this bastard of a card instead of clearing your field on your turn.

Anyway, what an incredible card. One of the biggest wrenches you can throw in any enemy's plans, especially in the blue mirror match. With Teferi, you save your mana to counter their spells like normal. But wait! Instead of untapping and going on your way like normal, just throw your creature of choice on their turn so it's ready to beat face and/or activate its ability on yours.

All attached to one of Magic's greatest heroes. An auto-include for this set. 5/5 every time.

244667: Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.author: DarthParallax
244667: Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.text_parsed:
This is ironically the FTV: Legends card that makes me saddest. Not mad at all- just sad.

They showed THE best card in the set first, and literally ever since the 2nd-15th cards, I got less, and less, and less excited. Teferi set the bar so high, and I THOUGHT he was going to be the 'average' bar of the set's quality. Which would have been FREAKIN SWEET and guaranteed us a set truly worthy of the name "From the Vault: Legends"

Even if From the Vault: Relics, From the Vault: Dragons, and From the Vault: Exiled's tradition is redeemed by From the Vault: Realms, of the Five Vaulted Sets so far, "Legends" had by far the coolest name and the most potential. And they dropped the ball. And part of it was because they included no cards that were particularly more 'oh WOW-inspiring' than Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.

He's a great card, and a great guy, and he earned his spot. But he deserved to have better companions to share the Vault with.

244667: Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.author: Continue
244667: Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir.text_parsed:
Knowledge Pool.

To clarify, Teferi makes it such that opponents may only cast spells at sorcery speed; that is, during their turn and on an empty stack. Whenever they cast a spell, Knowledge Pool kicks in, their spell is exiled, and they cannot cast another spell exiled by Knowledge Pool because it would no longer be at sorcery speed.

Unless an opponent has a game-winning board, or can cast something game-winning from anywhere but their hand, you have won.

244668: Oona, Queen of the Fae.author: Zoah
244668: Oona, Queen of the Fae.text_parsed:
She mills and exiles cards.
She makes tokens that fly and basically have flash.
She flies and, to date, has higher power/toughness than any other blue wizard in the game.

Any of these three, by themselves, make her good. She has all of them.
She's also versatile, and will have no trouble in any deck that is black or blue.

She's also survives most kill spells. Terror, doomblade? Nope, she's quite black. lightning bolt, Flame slash? Nope, she's too big. To top that of she's a blue faerie, so the player will have a fist full of Spellstutter Sprites and Familiar's Ruses to defender her.

If you can criticize her, she has a heavy cost, but it's worth it, and you really don't want her unless you have manna to burn anyway. For a nice meaty six cost, it's hard to do better. 5/5

244668: Oona, Queen of the Fae.author: DarthParallax
244668: Oona, Queen of the Fae.text_parsed:
This one's like Kresh. Jund decks in Standard used other cards. Faerie decks in Standard used other cards. Standard cards don't belong in From the Vault. Sure, Lorwyn/Shadowmoor might be considered old- if you have the attention span of a squirrell. Just because a card is strong, and good in Commander, doesn't mean it's From the Vault quality.
It needs to have a combination of antiqueness and power that makes it special.
Every From the Vault card needs to pass what I call the ''M10 Lightning Bolt" test, or it's a mistake.
Granted, 'Exiled' and 'Relics' this was even more true than it normally should be-

but we could have seen some Xth Edition/Onslaught Pit Fighters, or some Ravnican Guildmasters, and that would have been reasonable to call "From the Vault" than all these Alarans. A good card that is special for no other reason than that it is good is not actually special. Black Lotus can be Force of Willed. Force of Will can be Mana Drained. Every block will have some good cards (not that good, but still good).

That's why instead of the "Mythic Rare Legendary Creature- Fancy Typeline" test, I use the M10 Lightning Bolt Test to judge From the Vault cards. Which is particularly awesome because it works on cards of all rarities, types and colors, can apply to both cheap and expensive cards, and never fails.

@Cyberium: Actually Oona is the Irish name of the Queen of the Faries or Queen of the Elphame. She was the wife of the last high king of the Daoine Sidhe. According to wikipedia, alternative spellings can be: Oonagh, or Una, or Uonaidh.

None of this is too surprising since lorwyn is based heavily on that mythology. Oona makes a great addition to the legends box, being that she is the primary antagonist for two sets. Legends wasn't just about reprinting the most powerful legendary creatures, its also about the lore. Vorthos represent.

244669: Rafiq of the Many.author: DarthParallax
244669: Rafiq of the Many.text_parsed:
Dear art critics: you know, if they had to put in ANOTHER Alaran in the set, at least they gave Rafiq a horse...er...I mean...lion o.o
Reminds me of Knight of the Reliquary in DD: KvD.
Yes, the old art IS better. BUT! Every Knight needs a steed. That's always been a rule, and it's STILL a rule. :)
9/13/2011

2 Years Later...
EDIT: Hmmm...You know....I am beginning to think that FTV: Legends is going to AGE a lot better than From the Vault: Dragons did. :P

See....yes, there were all these Alaran cards in it? And we really didn't think we needed/wanted half of them in the set? But now here were are, and so far I still can't think of a Commander I'd rather have in these colors than Rafiq. He's the Go-To man for the colors. He might rise in value sometime when you least expect. He's very customizable, good with a Tokens strategy combined with Sublime Archangel, or good as an "All-In Me" Superhero guy, and you can slide Kond into the 99...when you would probably not want to run Kond as the Commander..

Kiki-Jiki and Ulamog were actually already good picks, and darn it if we haven't seen any other reprints of Eldrazi Titans since then...if by the end of the 20th Year Anniversary celebrations, demand for FTV: L hasn't picked up, I'll be surprised. We'll have to see what is in the 2nd Wave of Commander.

I don't think Kresh is the ONLY Commander for his colors....ditto about Sharuum, although she's much more highly played.

I think if they'd left the Alaran Vault members to Progenitus and Rafiq, they would have done well.

A Shard Legend (Rafiq)
A Guild Legend (Momir Vig)
A 5-Color Legend (Progenitus)
A Colorless Legend (Ulamog)
A Hybrid Legend (Oona)
A Weatherlight (Captain Sisay)
An Elder Dragon (Vaevictis Asmadi or Palladia-Mors)
with two changes for Sharuum and Kresh, this is looking a lot better..?

I mean...this was ALMOST a good set, and while it's overloaded on Shards Legends, of the many present, a couple of them deserve to be here. I think Rafiq is one of them.

I also think this set would have profited greatly from including a Glissa the Traitor or Skithyrix the Blight Dragon. Yes, recent cards, but they actually left a big impact on people.

But now here were are, and so far I still can't think of a Commander I'd rather have in these colors than [autocard]Rafiq[/autocard]. He's the Go-To man for the colors. He might rise in value sometime when you least expect. He's very customizable, good with a Tokens strategy combined with [autocard]Sublime Archangel[/autocard], or good as an "All-In Me" Superhero guy, and you can slide [autocard]Kond[/autocard] into the 99...when you would probably not want to run Kond as the Commander..

[autocard]Kiki-Jiki[/autocard] and [autocard]Ulamog[/autocard] were actually already good picks, and darn it if we haven't seen any other reprints of Eldrazi Titans since then...if by the end of the 20th Year Anniversary celebrations, demand for FTV: L hasn't picked up, I'll be surprised. We'll have to see what is in the 2nd Wave of Commander. 

I don't think Kresh is the ONLY Commander for his colors....ditto about [autocard]Sharuum[/autocard], although she's much more highly played. 

I think if they'd left the Alaran Vault members to Progenitus and Rafiq, they would have done well. 

A Shard Legend (Rafiq)
[b]A Guild Legend[/b] (Momir Vig)
A 5-Color Legend (Progenitus)
A Colorless Legend (Ulamog)
A Hybrid Legend (Oona) 
A Weatherlight (Captain Sisay) 
[b]An Elder Dragon[/b] (Vaevictis Asmadi or Palladia-Mors)
with two changes for Sharuum and Kresh, this is looking a lot better..?

I mean...this was ALMOST a good set, and while it's overloaded on Shards Legends, of the many present, a couple of them deserve to be here. I think Rafiq is one of them.

I also think this set would have profited greatly from including a [autocard]Glissa the Traitor[/autocard] or [autocard]Skithyrix the Blight Dragon[/autocard]. Yes, recent cards, but they actually left a big impact on people.

244670: Cao Cao, Lord of Wei.author: Fireballmage
244670: Cao Cao, Lord of Wei.text_parsed:
I don't like what this card represents. If Wizards pays too much attention to the secondary market, reprints become limited, and the game suffers for it. The only reason why Xiahou Dun (The actual legend that was requested for this release) is so expensive is his scarcity. Since the card is a popular EDH card that does something completely unique (No other Black card can return so many card types from the graveyard), he should have been reprinted.

Instead, we got Cao Cao, Lord of Wei. Who wanted this card? It's a poor EDH general, and a card that does something a lot of black cards already do. The only really likeable thing about him is his importance to the Romance of Three Kingdoms plot.

244672: Kresh the Bloodbraided.author: BrokenAllies
244672: Kresh the Bloodbraided.text_parsed:
Oh... Oh I love him. And not in a Twillight-gay way, but in a very manly, bro-to-bro love... *coughs*
ANYWHO!

@LetsMakeAName

If your Thromok was 200 when he was Doombladed and you still had your Corpsejack Menace, I would imagine that instead of 200 counters, Kresh would've gotten 400 counters. Effectively making him a 403/403.


Now, I get that people would want other legends in this set. But Kresh is amazing. He enables you to play 3 awesome colors, whilst ALSO enabling a ton of Graveyard shenanigans.

I play him in one of the funniest EDH decks I've ever had. No game is ever the same. It's not too powerful, to scare away my casual playgroup and it IS really competitative.
Kresh gets alot of hate from other players, while playing. But that is okay. Just build your deck around the CONCEPT of him, instead of only him. Deathbringer Thoctar is a good card to have in play aswell.
That, plus Doubling Season or Corpsejack Menace , makes you kill off 1/1's only to get an ADDITIONAL counter on Deathbringer.
IF Kresh is on the battlefield, nice, he gets big, if not? Well, you kill alot of tokens.

All in all. I think Kresh is best when you build a concept deck with him to benefit from all the other shenanigans, RATHER than building a deck, with him in the center. He is too expencive and too easy to get rid off for that.

244674: Doran, the Siege Tower.author: DarthParallax
244674: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_parsed:
Fixed FTV:L list-
1. Vaevictis Asmadi--come on. Commander = EDH = Give us a non-Bolas Elder Dragon, please!
just for the memories
2. Emrakul the Aeons Torn--Putting in the second-best one because the first best is banned is actually counter to the spirit of their borkenness.
3. Progenitus--5 colors. reasonable include if the other Alarans are purged.
4. Tsabo Tavoc--I think Phyrexia needed a represent, and she would have looked cool next to Sisay.
5. Phage the Untouchable-much more Vorthos-tastic than Visara.
6. Captain Sisay-autoinclude.
7. Teferi, Mage of Zhalfir-Spot on. Direct hit. The best spoiler was spoiled first though, so that's a marketing fail.
8. Doran the Siege Tower-Wedge Commander.
9. Arcanis the Omnipotent-
10. Ravnican Legend- everyone loves Ravnica. come on.
11. Sek-kuar, Deathkeeper-a three color Legendary Goblin?! :D
12. Mishra, Artificer Prodigy- because no Urza creature card exists.
13. That Which Was Taken- hey, it's a Legend. a rather important one, that synergizes with Legends. And it's the only Kamigawa Legend I can pronounce :P
14. ? ? ?
15. Mikaeus, the Lunarch

This is just a rough sketch. I kept about 1/3 of the cards the same, so it's not like a think the set was a TOTAL fail- it just could have been the most amazing thing ever....and.....wasn't.

It's already been talked into the ground, but I think I raise up very fair points when it comes to:
Ravnicans, Phyrexians, an Elder Dragon and Mishra. Easy places to put in cards that would have been appreciated far, far more for their history than the Alarans are for their power. I killed Oona because the Faerie Deck that was such a menace didn't actually use her, so she shouldn't get credit. Vendillion Clique is another story entirely.

EDIT: Here's the thing. I think FTV: Legends was tailored way too much to 'supposedly' please Commander crowds. I've kept returning to the set time and again, trying to decide whether I should buy it. That alone is a warning sign. FtV: Dragons, Exiled, and Relics were so amazingly enticing, that the only reason I don't have Dragons and Exiled is money. Relics I emptied my pockets for the second I could get my hands on it.

While I know that gameplay-wise, the Legend Rule is almost a strict drawback, except for the Commander format where you NEED a Legend to play, the whole idea of Legendary creatures that have personal names and stories opens up Magic: the Gathering to be 10,000x more interesting than Chess, even though from a 'complicated skill-testing game' view, Chess has Magic beat. The inequality of the cards cuts the real decision tree down to size by a lot.



I understand Commander to a novice level. I don't believe that Phage or Mishra would be particularly impressive as Commanders. But for the Vorthos Super Nerds who read all the novels and eat up webcomics and keep waiting with baited breath for the next Savor the Flavor Column to tell us what's actually going on, Mishra and Phage are some of the all-time Super Stars of the History of Magic.

For example, the Mirari appeared in FTV: Relics. I don't think it's quite a Mythic Rare-powerful card. It looks cool and strong, but also seems very weak compared to its fellow Relics. But if you look up the story, it is so deeply entrenched in the entire history of the blocks that they couldn't NOT put it in. It is indeed a Relic. An artifact with lots of history behind it.

Mishra, Artificer Prodigy is more than just a Time Spiral card. He's the character that represents half of the Brother's War, one of the most monumental events in Multiverse history. Ditto Vaevictus Asmadi.

Phage might be a poor Commander, but she's excellent in your 99, and she was a main character for 2 whole blocks: Odyssey and Onslaught. She even merged with Akroma, Angel of Wrath to make Karona, the False God. Maybe Karona would have been more appropriate, since she's more playable as a Commander.

My point is that the thought of a set called 'From the Vault: Legends' makes me think of much, much more than 'just' "can I win the game with this card?"

Hell, NORIN THE WARY, or the infamous Hans, would have been very well appreciated to see in this set, even though one isn't a card (yet!) and the other sort of sucks.

This set should have thought of the Vorthoses, and it actually didn't. It makes me wonder if Relics' wonderful Vorthosness was actually an accident and WOTC was just thinking 'what are some overpowered cards we can print in shiny to jack up the price?'

244674: Doran, the Siege Tower.author: Fanaticmogg
244674: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_parsed:
Inside Out is the anti-Doran.

- It is the two colors that Doran isn't.
- It's a hybrid, making it really easy to cast compared to Doran's triple-color cost.
- It's an Instant, which is pretty much as far as you can get from a creature, card type-wise.
- Doran is from Lorwyn, Inside Out is from Shadowmoor (the plane, not the set)
- It kills Doran outright.
- It can do a decent impression of Doran's ability anyways, turning your unblocked 2/10 into a scary tower of damage. It can also make 10/2s nearly harmless.

Come to think of it, I never heard about what happened to Doran during Shadowmoor...

244675: Progenitus.author: JaxsonBateman
244675: Progenitus.text_parsed:
Progenitus, for a lot of players, taught us a valuable lesson about how there's pretty much no creature in the game that can't be stopped in some way - even if some are ridiculously hard to stop. When I first got myself a Progenitus just after I started playing, I was very gleeful - "protection from everything" just sounded so omnipotent and devastating. But of course, some Googling made me realise that it wasn't so invulnerable...

I guess my point is that you could make the most sturdy creature there is - for example, a Progenitus made indestructible (perhaps via Darksteel Forge and Mycosynth Lattice). It can be killed by any clone effect. Alright, give it Undying via Mikaeus, the Unhallowed. It can still be bounced via Evacuation, and then countered. Alright, make it uncounterable via Gaea's Herald. It can still be exiled via Final Judgment, or sent to the bottom of your library via Terminus. Sure, you can get it out of exile with some cards, and can find it in your library with others, but at that point it's no longer the super survivable creature doing the work.

And yes, such a devastating combo such as Progenitus, Darksteel Forge, Mycosynth Lattice, Mikaeus the Unhallowed and Gaea's Herald is going to be very hard to stop for a random deck. But my point is, until they give a creature the ability "if this permanent would leave the battlefield, instead exile it, then return it to the battlefield under its owner's control" there's never going to be a creature that is outright unstoppable.

- shroud
- prevent all damage that would be done to ~~~~

Imagine if a lot of them were from the Kamigawa set. Things with "Spirit" or "Arcane" bonuses would be a joke, and there would be more complaints than there is now. At least they brought back one of the best (Kiki-Jiki, that is)

261321: Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre.author: DarthParallax
261321: Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre.text_parsed:
OK, Im going to shorten this rant into something...um, readable. :p

Commander comes from EDH. Elder Dragon Highlander. Does anyone even remember the Elder Dragons from Legends anymore? This is From the Vault: Legends. Where the hell is my foil Vaevictis Asmadi? Or maybe Chromium? I'll take Arcaddes Sabboth, even. It's really not that hard. Just not Bolas. I mean, Bolas WOULD have been nice...if he wasn't already in a From the Vault. I would almost, almost be ok with an actual Double Vault appearance by Bolas, if it meant the set no longer looked like --


From the Vault: New Stuff is Better than History. seriously. How many of these cards existed pre-8th Edition? Hell, how many of them existed pre-MENDING?! This isn't "From the Vault". This is "From my Trade Binder".


I mean, this set really kind of kicks the whole idea of the From the Vault series in the balls. Dragons, Exiled, Relics, and Legends. What else is a good topic for the Vault? I think this set really might have killed the series, unless the next one throws sanity out the window with "From the Vault: Power"

".... I play Ulamog... Hai Emrakul.. Oh, Nvm, Bai Emrakul. Good talking to you"
